I've had an amazing experience learning under Mr. Mendez. He has really made the experience studying this Full-Stack program worthwhile and extremely enjoyable and impactful. He would assist me in class whenever I had an issue and he would always find a way to fix the issue while also teaching what I did wrong and how I could improve with my developer career. I would highly recommend him as a mentor to anyone interested.

The course description did not match the teacher's approach to the class

I would like there to have been more structure on the part of the instructor as well as already created lesson plans and premade visual aids. This would allow us to save time on trying to create while explaining concepts and possibly allow for more interaction with the class as opposed to just explaining topics. In my opinion, It would be more beneficial for the class if there were more real life examples that show the concepts being taught which go over the concepts in real time from start to finish when applicable. I think the instructor is very knowledgable and experienced in the field but I feel he may be struggling to put his thoughts into words at times. On the positive side of things, he is very eager and willing to answer questions and has a very positive attitude towards the class. To be very transparent, I've had to find other sources on the internet to try and learn many of the concepts we have been taught up to this point.
Simon has been available and helpful whenever necessary.
Manish seems very experienced and knowledgeable and very supportive.
The 4 geeks curriculum was outdated and we had many issues with the system in the beginning. The instructor taught us the new version of the coding languages
Simon has been quick, responsive and available to assist with course material and assignments as well as career questions
He was very informative and patient with the class. We are all newbies. My only issue is that i wish he would use more relatable words for us non-techy people.
he has been very helpful

He has a strong accent making him hard to understand at times and consistently does not understand exactly what is being asked by the students. He lectures for 3 hours without any interaction from the class, and students have stopped trying to ask questions because there is a feeling like there is no use because the teacher is unable to understand the questions that students they have. I also do not feel that he is very familiar with the curriculum and consistently responds to questions with "Just google it and you can find out more" I don't believe that people are paying a considerable amount of money to be told that they should google the answer to their questions. In short, the way he conducts the course, it is a waste of time to go to class.
Unfortunately, I can not in good faith recommend 4 geeks to anyone I know, as I feel that it is equivalent to learning on your own.

Overall the prework was challenging. The course material seems comprehensive. I believe the instructors are qualified. I would like to see more preparation before each lesson to be clear on what is expected from me. I like the injection of state-of- art concepts by the experienced faculty and the frequent emphasis on topics beyond the course. Lastly, faculty have been accessible to support assignments and address my questions.  To improve experience I think it would help was we move forward to provide a clear overview on assignments and timing to help me prepare.
I am enjoying learning the field of data science up to this point and feel it is the right path for me from what I have seen so far.

If I wasn't on the Miami Tech Scholarship I would have abandoned this program. I would not pay for this. The teacher is trying his best, but is unable to connect with the students. He has a hard time understanding the questions students have, and after the students have tried many times to ask questions and received unsatisfactory responses, you can tell that people have stopped trying to ask questions. The teacher just speaks for 3 hours with barely any interaction. I could probably have a better learning experience just learning by myself, the group BootCamp setting has no advantages over me just learning by myself the way things are going at the moment.
I think the school is great and solves a very big need. I'm assuming the structure of the course will improve with each Cohort moving forward. If I can be part of that, I would be happy to do so.

This whole process has been a nightmare and there was a lot of miscommunication from the Administrator at MDC. Everything from the 4 geek system, to receiving a student card (i was sent from department to department on trying to get help) , to the outdated course and codespaces not working has been a total waste of money. I will not be recommending this college to anyone I know.

On the rare occasion Mr. Mendez was occupied and was unavailable , Mr. Smith gladly assisted me with any issue or question I may have had at the moment. He was a great help in these instances.

It's been very good. The first class I was in was too slow, and now it's fast, so I need to pick up the speed on my end. The Director, teachers, and the TA in my current class have made themselves readily available which I appreciate immensely.

I would recommend however the flux project we are doing is puzzling, because flux is not used much now. I think redux should be incorporated instead. There is also very little material provided for beginners. The reading seems to be written by someone who assumes the student knows what they're doing, and usually, we don't.
Lots of information in a short amount of time. Not for the faint of heart.

If feels like the 4Geeks academy Europe is out of capacity to ensure the promoted service when it comes to close work with the students. Luckily we have a fantastic professor for course, but the servise of mentoring or responding to the students needs at the moment when it is necessary is not being provided. It also getting tiring for student to repeat many times the same questions... Also I think the schools havent provided the communication when it comes to the specific days when mentors will not be available. Several cancelations have been because there "something comes up!" or it has been sometimes impossible to find the response moment to talk with some mentor WHEN the question are being arised. For the Europe part-time bootcamp we have ONLY 3 mentors from whom there is only ONE that have a decent attitude towards the students regards to the way of explaining things and being open to solve with matters that is needed. BUT  that person is so busy with other stuff.

Leonardo is fantastic professor who try his best to help us out regards to the needs, and however there is a many things which is not on his hand to deal with. We as student understand that, however, he has to hear our concerns because he is only one from academy who we meet regularly... Once again, in my opinion academy is not providing the service and support for the students as it was promoted. this way building false expectations to one who invest money in studies and in your organisation.

I have really enjoyed the experience so far, but I do have some feedback.

It seems that each class is unstructured. From my perspective, there usually is no set topic, or we sometimes cover multiple topics in one class. Sometimes Manny discusses topics, that although relevant and helpful to learn about, may be a bit too advanced for us.

I appreciate Manny's willingness to go far and beyond to teach us, but due to the fast pace of the course, I'm not sure it's the best use of time.
amazing!!!!!  So helpful and supportive

Manny possesses a wealth of intelligence and patience, qualities that shine especially during our live coding sessions. His spontaneity in deciding to code examples on the spot is admirable, though it sometimes leads to unforeseen challenges mid-way. This approach keeps the sessions dynamic and engaging, albeit occasionally less structured.

I've also explored other educational content for comparison, such as Dr. Angela Yu's courses on Udemy. Dr. Yu adopts a highly structured format, comprising an introduction, a problem related to the topic, and a step-by-step solution, followed by a test problem for independent practice. This systematic approach aids in clarity and understanding.

While Manny's style differs, often encountering unexpected problems, these moments offer valuable insights into real-world coding challenges.

It's a unique learning experience where we witness problem-solving in action, enhancing our understanding of the unpredictability and flexibility required in coding.

Andres has been exceptional, consistently demonstrating remarkable dedication and support. As my go-to person for resolving complex issues, his expertise and approachability have been invaluable. Whenever I grapple with challenging problems, Andres always offers insightful solutions and guidance.

In addition to his one-on-one support, Andres plays a crucial role in our class, particularly during live coding sessions with Manny. His attentiveness and readiness to assist Manny increased our productivity during the coding session. His ability to anticipate and address issues as they arise during these live projects is impressive, contributing significantly to the overall success of the class.
Very
El profe se esmeró mucho en ayudarnos con cada proyecto, y eso suma un montón. Agradezco la predisposición y la dedicación en la clase de hoy.

So this program has been great as a stepping stone to get into the tech industry and becoming a Full-Stack Developer. However, the latter half of the program has been an absolute struggle, where I don't feel comfortable trying to get into the industry yet, I still feel like theres concepts that I haven't grasped yet. I will say the difficulty of the projet grew exponentially once we got into APIs and using React where I feel like I'm running around trying to find other resources in order to properly know how to code something on my own. Also the lack of demo videos for these complex projects did not help, as I feel like Alejandro Sanchez does a great job of explaining all the concepts.

Emmanuel's a great teacher, I have to say he's always there and available for us to consult with and even goes out of his way to make powerpoint presentations for class, have office hours on days we dont have class to be able to ask questions about projects and move forward with the class. However, perhaps I just don't click with his teaching style as I really don't think I've grasped a lot of concepts that by now if this curriculum were supposed to leave me ready to pursue a career right out of the bootcamp I should have already. This also being his first course teaching, he's just getting into how to teach and perhaps needs to cut his teeth a bit more. Again, not for his lack of trying, and he's very knowledgeable, he's just got learn how to translate some of the concepts to people who have never coded before like myself.

No complaints with Andres, same notes as before. Extremely knowledgeable and is almost like a bridge between the knowledge that were learning and us understanding it. He's always available on Slack during class and always answering questions that we may have with documentation and examples, he's an absolute asset to 4Geeks.

Having gone through the entire course, I can comfortably say yes I would absolutely recommend 4Geeks to anyone...that lives in Miami and can acquire the scholarship. I do appreciate the fact that I had to go through an interview process to determine whether or not I was in the correct mindset to be invested in to pursue this career. On the other hand I don't know if it was just my cohort, but there we're a couple people that I have NO IDEA how they passed their interview or even got in, like they definitely paid the $10K for the course or had some sort of connection because they don't add anything at all to the class and quite frankly seem even more lost than I am, and I'm not exactly a coding whiz. Also, the course itself is VERY fast, for people that already have a good foundation in coding this course would be great for them. For someone like me on the other hand that had no experience in coding was a huge challenge and wished there was a more indepth course to really grasp concepts

It's been a good experience overall but I feel that the curriculum is a little crammed. It could be an additional month or 2 and have the chance to go more in depth on certain topics before moving onto the next one.

He's done a good job overall, especially for this being his first time teaching. He's very knowledgeable regarding the topics but can be a bit scattered at times. I'm sure this will get better the more he teaches. He's also always willing to help if you have an issue.

Andres is awesome and I'm so happy that he was the mentor for our class. He is very knowledgeable regarding the curriculum and the topics we cover and his experience with also completing the program has given me hope. He is extremely kind and helpful and goes out of his way to ensure that we are getting the most out of the bootcamp.

It has been a great experience but I think that it could be better for the price. The topics could go more into detail and the schedule could be improved upon also so that you actually have time to understand the concepts before being thrown into the deep end with projects.
como preferencia personal, me gusta mas el backend pero soy consciente de que hay que tocar todos los palos, pero me gustaria mas backend que dare cuando termine aqui
New teacher is great. Samir has great teaching instincts, and is as helpful as they come. I’m very happy with the way the course is progressing.

He is an excellent teacher, with great instincts for teaching and guiding others in learning. I appreciate that he is well prepared for class. And goes through the projects beforehand. I appreciate that he makes every effort to have everyone feel involved and heard. He takes the time to address all questions and is very kind and patient with everyone. Samir is a wonderful teacher and knowledgeable. 4geeks picked a great one for this course.
Excellent, knowledgeable, professional, reliable.
The way 4geeks was able to pivot and salvage something that wasn’t progressing well is admirable and shows that 4geeks is ran by very competent people. Will recommend.

Lo mismo que siempre he comentado, en la parte del pre-work si o si se debe hacer énfasis en los estudiantes que van a ingresar a la academia en aprender y tener conocimientos básicos para al menos llegar ubicados con los temas (así sea por encima). One small recommendation. You should pair up groups 4-5 people, for study groups. So we have a set group of people with whom we can work and set up meetings. If you create the groups, and set up a "president" for each group, it will be easier for peopl.

its been a lot the last few months, make think of quitting almost everyday. To get mentorships is hard most of them are during the class hours, which does not make sense. Otherwise you have to book one like 2 weeks in advance for an specific topic

It too expensive for what I get, sometimes I think I learn a lot but i am just scraping on the surface, meaning I dont have time to internailize the last topic before I get to the next, making it extremly frustrating

Se nota que sabe bastante y al momento de hacer preguntas es bastante resolutivo y rapido para encontrar los errores que nos pueden estar conflictuando.  En ocasiones no responde oportunamente el canal de slack para preguntas pequeñas que en muchos casos te pueden estancar por mucho tiempo.

There's some disorganization, some things get lost in the process, there was a lot of confusion on simple stuff such as how to start a project, whether or not we needed to fork it, etc. Also in my personal case it looks like the person who was helping me get started skipped a whole step so I didn't receive any payment notices until after I asked how I could pay. One good thing is that it's gotten better now.
The bootcamp goes quite fast and for some topics I need to study a lot but the content of the class is dynamic and interesting
Excellent, collaborative and very helpful

great and simple explanation of difficult things

La única pega que le encuentro de momento es que no se puedan grabar todos los tramos de una clase. Es decir, empieza la clase, estamos un par de horas más o menos, que se graban, se deja de grabar cuando nos separan en salas, y al volvernos a juntar, si se están resolviendo dudas, no se vuelven a grabar.  Esto, para los ppiantes, está muy mal, pq no podemos volver a acceder a esas consultas. Las mentorias, como son con cita, que es comprensible, hay veces que no tienes citas disponibles durante demasiado tiempo, con lo que te quedas al descubierto. Rsas grabaciones del final serían una ayuda.
Está siendo maravilloso. Aunque a veces me sienta sobrepasada, creo que hacer este bootcamp ha sido la mejor decisión que podía tomar.

Estupenda! Es destacablemente buena ayudándonos a gestionar los momentos de autocrítica y duda, ya que nos recuerda que no estamos solos y el sentimiento de "no llegar a todo" es común en la profesión. Su "meme" oficial sobre la búsqueda en google de un junior y un senior no se me olvidará jamás.

homework always checked timely; advice given if needed.

Although we are only 2 weeks the feeling is not at all positive. Starting with the presentation of the first day by the director, I appreciate Director’s motivating message but his English was improvable. I'm not native but if 4Geeks offers such bootcamp in English for Europeans, the director should have a decent level (I know, he apologized several times for his level). As 4Geeks website states "No previous experience needed", but then you see with astonishment how fast the teacher advances and although you may have a thousand doubts in your head, you can hardly put them in order. Of course, there is a Prework module, Slack chats to assist students...However, even if I have previous experience with programming, Github, CLI, I have talked to my peers and they seem to have the same feeling. I'm sure the teacher is a really good professional, but being educator implies other skills. Again, only 2 weeks yet but I personally did 2 months of Full Stack July 2023 and know what I mean

Guys I have recommended 4Geeks since July 2023 (I did almost 2 months of FS part time but had to quit due to personal reasons and paid 1000 euros charge, still don't know WHY you require that much....). Not only recommended friends and coworkers but also to my couple (she will study same program as me by summer this year), but now it is very difficult for me to recommend 4Geeks.

Have done bootcamps before. One was an expensive disaster, and ignored every piece of feedback and plea asking for help to the point of begging, the other was a fraction of the cost and was so good I took 2 courses with them & took to leaving them great reviews without even being asked. Here, there is a lot of Googling the answer and having to work backwards because there is a lot of jumping around screen and the explanations are extremely confusing to the point of frustration. This was sold as a course of ´repetition through learning´ yet I frequently have NO idea how to even approach a problem and I am expected to be self-guiding. I have redone all exercises and find myself extremely uncomfortable each time.

Edgar tries to explain what he is doing but uses FAR too much tech talk and seems to forget that we have never lived and breath code before. When a problem in an exercise is given, each time, we NEED to read and stop and be ASKED: What do WE think the issue is? How do WE think we will solve this, string by string, carefully and methodically and wait for student responses (i.e; do we need to set up any variables, define a new function, what existing ones should/can we look for, if I write this, can you tell me what I am missing) otherwise it goes completely over my head and there's too much to even formulate a question for.

Right now we are just going through answers for the 1 or 2 problems we are given but no opportunity to apply and make enough mistakes. Not sure if the breakout period is too long - teaching/learning/therory should be longer for class time as we can work in pairs in our own time. Also not sure if and when is appropriate to reach out to ask for help.

-La densidad del contenido (específicamente) audiovisual es muy pobre (El promedio de tiempo de contenido real de las clases, no supera los 50 minutos).
-Los temas se tratan de forma superflua. 
-Las clases no se ven preparadas, las clases muchas veces se volvieron en hacer la práctica todos juntos, cuando se supone que debe ser trabajo autónomo estas guías.
-Muchas veces la explicación de los proyectos es casi nula, o pobre, lo cuál no ayuda mucho a aprender a abarcar los problemas que se presentan
-El profesor, muchas veces argumente que los temas serán tocados después, y pocas veces es realmente así.
-A la hora de preguntar, la mayoría de respuestas por parte del profesor se basan en: Ya lo vimos, mira (imperativamente) el vídeo que ahí está, ese tema lo trataremos luego, ó lee bien las instrucciones.

Pero si la denominación tampoco es que es un profesor, sino un mentor... tampoco es el mejor de los mentores, pues sus respuestas son insuficientes.
Finalmente, si se le evalúa como un "Guía"; diría que es un guía normal, ordinario.
Es muy presto a cualquier cosa, y hace un buen ambiente en la clase, Sin embargo se nota que sus funciones son muy reducidas, así que me abstengo de dar una puntuación significativa

At this point I have mixed feelings about the program. After being switched into Shane and Valerie's class, I now see what classes should've been like from the beginning. Shane does an amazing job at explaining everything, I just feel so behind on everything that it feels like I'm constantly trying to catch up. At this point, we're working on Flask and Back-end and I'm still trying to fully get the functionality of Javascript. It really demonstrates that the catalyst of what makes this program successful is having a professor that knows how to teach the material. If I could somehow go back to Javascript to get the foundations solid, everything else would fall into place.

Words cannot explain at how much of a godsend Shane is, I had a React Refresher one on one which I'm using as a reference to work on my current projects, and it really helped grasp concepts that I didn't get in the beginning. He just knows how to structure class in what feels like a more productive manner.

No change with Andres, still helpful as always. He gets a 10 because he I'm sure was a catalyst in getting our cohort switched to Shane's. But yes he's always available, and hes a great source of information to fall back on.

At this point, I can see that 4Geeks has a decent framework to work off of, but it really depends on the professor that you get. After my first couple months in the program, with no idea what to expect I didn't know at what level of understanding I had to be at, and thus now in retrospect I see that we are all extremely lost and looking to other resources like Udemy and freeCodeCamp to make sense of what little information we know. At the point that our cohort was switched which was about 2-3 weeks before our final project, just feels like too little too late, and at best I have a fractured foundation on which to continue my studies and try to piece together and come out successful on the other side. Perhaps with a better method of deciding who teaches, or even hiring from within using former students as teachers who know what we're currently going through, perhaps the program would be more cohesive in its learning style.

Siento que a veces las clases no están suficientemente estructuradas y se van desarrollando según memoria, a veces esto da lugar a un poco de perdida de tiempo. Ejemplo, si se va a practicar en ejercicios de la academia o algun proyecto aparte, se deberia tener listo el proyecto y como se hara para no gastar ese tiempo en pensar en las cosas y evitar errores. También siento que se pierde tiempo en mucha platica tomando consideración que nuestras clases son cortas y solo 3 veces a la semana. Reconozco que la clase es la empieza y da cuerda pero se deberia ser un poco mas estricto en esto, habemos otros que queremos aprovechar mas el tiempo. En general mi experiencia ha sido bastante buena, pero supongo que este es el punto de la encuesta no tener miedo a decir algunas cosas. Creo que lo podría resumir en el hecho que siento que tenemos muy poca clase entonces me gustaría que cada minuto se aprovechara al maximo, 0 tiempo perdido.

Por mi parte estudie 3 meses solo antes de entrar al bootcamp y aun en temas que siento que ya domino Samu demuestra que su razonamiento en hacer las cosas es mas elevado que lo que uno podria sacar o imaginar. En terminos de caracter y personalidad es muy honesto, trabajador, empatico y amable, nunca se molesta o se irrita por mas que se le pregunta lo mismo mil veces y eso pasa bastante. It has been made clear that Google for example use the ´FizzBuzz´ test in interviews, meaning that people would be expected to turn up, memorise that and deliver from memory.

Samir has been great. Very patient, insightful, knowledgeable, and well spoken. The language barrier was tough to deal with when we had the previous instructor and it made a huge difference when the change was made.

Data Scientist and ML course content seems to require a good background in Python, supplemental instruction, and extra study hours to get the most out of assignments. However, there are a number of mentors to assist with assignments and career support to help transition into this field.

The people are great at 4 geeks. I feel like I am talking to actual people. As always the coursework and the sequence can be improved, and I am sure it is a continual process, but what I think is the best aspect of 4Geeks is that you get to interact with real people who are helping you to get to the level of expertise that they have. This is the separator between learning on your own versus doing a BootCamp, the guidance and human interaction.
I would recommend 4geeks to anyone looking to get an intense experience with actual people to break into the tech industry.
Solo por las horas continuas no pondría el 10, puedes estudiar 2 hrs diarias, pero 3 (aunque sean solo 3 días) se vuelve cansado

So far so good, it certainly has been fast-paced (which was to be expected).  There is only so much time to fully review the work that we complete and access the mentors/professors, but I feel that the intention is there to help each student along.  I would say for those entering this bootcamp with zero experience prior in the world of coding/computer science, be sure to take some time to fully analyze the world of data science/machine learning before embarking on this journey!  Other than that, I would say 4Geeks does a good job of covering the topics and assignments, with a knowledgeable staff.
Alex (Robert) is very knowledgable and able to convey the material with a thorough understanding of the principles and discipline that is DS/MS.

Estando ya en la recta final, siento que hay muchas cosas que me han fallado. La experiencia general es buena gracias a los profesores que tengo y los compañeros que me han tocado. No he estado en otras cohortes pero sinceramente creo que la nuestra tiene un ambiente inmejorable y hemos creado lazos maravillosos. 
Sin embargo, el temario se me ha quedado corto para el precio del bootcamp... Hay explicaciones y ejercicios anticuados, con tecnologías que no están al día. Hay test que fallan y proyectos que dan la sensación de pasar de aprender a leer a tener que escribir El Quijote. 
Entiendo que el tiempo es limitado y tampoco puedo pretender entenderlo todo en 2 días, pero viendo un módulo de python no me atrevo a decir que lo he aprendido. 
Si fuera más asequible sería una buena experiencia, pero creo que "lo venden" como algo que no es.
Es un buen tío, pero le falta mas preparación en la clase con casos reales que vamos a ver en el mundo laboral

Realmente no podría haber esperado un profesor mejor. Es cercano, amable, paciente y explica las cosas las veces que haga falta y con los ejemplos que haga falta para que podamos entenderlo todo. Agradezco haber caído en su cohorte porque dudo que la experiencia hubiese sido tan buena con otros profesores. Si el "overall satisfaction" del bootcamp es positivo, es totalmente gracias a él, a Romi, y a los compañeros que me han tocado.

Maravillosa, divertida, directa... Romi es una teacher assistant de matrícula. Nos ayuda muchísimo, aporta siempre otro punto de vista y nos ayuda a adentrarnos mejor en el temario. Sus consejos como ex-alumna la hacen todavía más increíble ya que vemos dónde podemos llegar con esfuerzo y ganas.

Lamentablemente, más cerca del final de curso, no siento que la inversión (en mi caso) sea adecuada. Tal vez, y ojalá, cambie de opinión tras titularme y ver el abanico de oportunidades que hay más allá del bootcamp (ya que 4Geeks es mucho más que este curso) pero en este punto, y tal vez movida por el estrés de las últimas semanas y proyecto final, no me veo recomendando la academia ya que la calidad del temario se queda corta por el precio y la magnitud de la academia.
Mezclan gente que ya sabe con gente como yo que empezamos de cero, entonces nos quedamos atras siempre.

He tenido unos mentores increíbles pero la verdad el curso deja mucho que desear, siento que al terminar no tendré el conocimiento para abrir un proyecto sin template ya que no se enfoca ningún módulo en eso y es algo que es parte del día a día de los developers, la verdad me gustaría que a la hora de vender el curso se enfocaran menos en marketing y más en la realidad, he aprendido muchas cosas pero las últimas partes se han enfrentado con mucha rapidez, además también e de decir que se debería tomar en cuenta que alguien que tiene un trabajo a tiempo completo no es capaz de hacer este curso con el entendimiento completo, se venden muchas cosas “maravillosas” y a medida que uno se va metiendo en este mundo y explorando las ofertas de trabajo y las redes se da cuenta que esto es solo un inicio muy muy básico para comenzar en este mundo, espero encontrar trabajo y seguir formándome.

Quizás el hecho de que esperemos que nos expliquen en las clases hace que desarrollemos menos el bootcamp por nosotros mismos. Otra cosa es que quizás el nivel del grupo está algo desbalanceado y como "trabajamos" juntos en clase hace que todo esté siendo algo más desorganizado esta primera semana. También la obligatoriedad de asistencia a las clases es quizás incensario cuando se nos exige preparar las primeras lecciones por nosotros mismos. Los ejercicios son algo corto y si los llevamos hechos se nos queda media clase "vacía".

The material and methodology is really good. I was skeptical at first, but I can attest now that it is working for me (and I am not the most logically inclined person).

My main issue is with the teaching method. For now, both of the mentors main concern seems to be to get to the solution to any question as fast as possible. Interest in the learning process of the student and in meeting the student where they currently stand seems to be secondary, if it is a concern at all.

Comments like "why did you do X? I did not tell you to do X" or "you were supposed to only copy a part of the solution but copied all of it instead" (with an amused undertone) are not helpful, but clearly do show that there are some gaps in the students understanding. So why not start with some explainations first and making the solution secondary until it is clear that the student has understood?

Generally, the experience is good. Nikhils demos and explainations are solid and very useful for me once I use them to revise on my own time.

Suggestion for improvement: some rhetorical training for better presentation of the material. Less reliance on filler phrases, like the very common "this is a thing". What is this "thing" exactly? Better explainations could be (for the sake of example):
- This is another array method to add to your toolbox.
- This is a workaround you can use once you get stuck.
- This is what we consider the best practice.

Right now, I am much more comfortable looking up the answers to my questions by myself.

So far the material is not new to me for the most part, so I'm not really relying on him. For me personally I get out of him what I need at the moment. I can't give him more than a 6 though, because he lacks very much the ability to make complex issues simple. In many cases the examples he gives make it more confusing. On multiple occasions I have been asked by class mates to explain some of the material because of this. Btw, I don't mind doing this, and I'm available to be a mentor for some of the subjects ;) you can call me :)

I wouldn't recommend 4geeks to a complete beginner, I see the issues my class mates have. The pace is too fast for beginners. But for people with some programming experience, that already know some databases, command line, git etc. I think it's a pretty good value for money.

After 6 weeks and the first survey, I can say the experience has improved. I'm not writing a lot in this survey since most of the initial concerns have been shared via email. I still agree to a large extent with the concerns shared, but I have managed to move forward and catch up and that helps in the perception of the bootcamp and boosts confidence for what is still to come. However, I think there are many things to improve including, but not limited, to: at least 1 recap class after 3 modules; improve the quality and the way some modules or part of them are organized (sometimes we start a topic by showing a script and outputs without having explained, and then after 2 lessons we see the explanation somewhere); the time spent in class because lately we see Edgar opening the class and after 45 minutes of fast explanation then creating breakout rooms)...

I think he is making an effort to improve the dynamics of the classes and to enhance the way he teaches. However, I see sometimes he is in a hurry to make the breakout rooms. Once in a breakout you are expecting him to guide you through the exercise but then there is a deathly silence and no one takes the initiative, and suddenly he disappears until the next help request. I know by heart he is a good person with a great background and professional skills, and I'm sure he will get better.

I didn't save my previous answer in a document, but sure you have it in a database. Since I joined 4Geeks in July 2023, I always put the academy in good words, strongly recommending to my colleagues in Nestlé (worldwide as I work with almost every country in the world due to my position in the organization). My mood has changed but I still want to see how things continue and if I'll be recommending in the future to my people. My girlfriend is a potential candidate for this same bootcamp this summer, we'll see if I still encourage her to dissuade...Let's keep working towards improve and maintain a positive bootcamp, thanks.

Tim is a great instructor and definitely has the experience to be teaching us. Rick was a fantastic instructor as well when filling in for Tim. Very helpful anytime I have questions. Theresa is a great TA as well. Live classes are helpful and I am happy we do group work and collaborate with one another. The one on one sessions with the mentors has been great. The only thing I think can be improved are the exercises. Sometimes I will run into problems with them. Some of the exercises has a tutorial video with an explanation which is great, but not all of them. Sometimes I have no idea what the answer is, I'll get the solution in the file, but I didn't learn anything from it. It helps to have an explanation go along with the answer. The exercises have helped me, but I think they can be improved. The learning curve is very steep as you progress through some exercises.

It is nice but I am investing more than 3 hours a day for the course and I still find myself falling behind, I hope we will start repeating things/concepts soon because otherwise I will not be able to submit the projects. For the lessons, they are a little fast and chaotic and the pair programming that happens after is sometimes even more confusing. Mentoring is working well but sometimes we "throw" out hours just for errors caused by the codespaces itself instead of of the code (that is not working because of these e.g. "connection errors", so it makes it more difficult to play with the code in the codespace) and other issues.

He is very nice and he knows what he is doing, I think the lesson/explanation gets confusing sometimes during the breakout rooms, not because of Edgar - he does his best - but because the solutions/instructions/the exercise is itself sometimes imprecise and confusing to us and then he will try to offer us a solution or help us in ways that then we do not always find in the 4geeks documentation. I realise self-research is an important part of the course but having to search continuously takes away so much time and energy, especially when looking at documentation that is not always easy to understand for beginners (and for mentors too sometimes)
I would recommend it only if they can really afford it, and if they already have some experience with coding/a degree in a scientific subject that they can fall back onto when looking for a job

Lo recomendaria porque obviamente yo estoy contenta con el curso (aun estamos al principio igualmente) pero siendo consciente de que es un commitment a ponerse a tope. Ahora lo pienso y que haya mentorias de por vida la verdad es un puntazo.

La didáctica del programa me gusta, como están estructurados los ejercicios y los proyectos paso por paso, además de las mentorías entre semana. Cuesta un poco al principio pero es normal, sobre todo si no se tiene una idea previa, pero bien, significa que aprendes. Los mentores son super simpáticos y el ambiente muy bueno en general. Lo que sí me gustaría es que los fines de semana hubiera la misma intensidad de mentorías, o por lo menos ''alguien'' siempre conectado, me ha ocurrido un par de findes (sobre todo domingos) que no hay nadie para preguntar. Entiendo que tenéis que descansar, por supuesto, pero por otro lado si tenemos un poco de libertad para organizarnos nuestro tiempo sería lo suyo que los fines de semana se pudieran resolver las dudas de la misma manera.
Creo que es muy pronto para esta pregunta, de momento "pasa palabra", pero supongo y espero que la respuesta sea muy probable

También recomendaría este tipo de bootcamp a gente que tuviera el tiempo suficiente para dedicarle, si no si es cierto que se hace difícil seguir el ritmo.

A muchos de hecho. Lo he tenido en mente, pero siempre y cuando estén en una situación en la que puedan hacerlo (estando en paro por decir un ejemplo), ya que de lo contrario quizás no les esté haciendo un favor.

Los ejercicios y los tiempos didácticos no son suficientes. Vamos muy rápido y no soy capaz de ponerme al día con los ejercicios aunque pida mentorías. Luego avanzamos a otro ejercicio y nos basamos en otro ejercicio que se supone que se ha tenido que hacer y la bola de nieve se hace más y más grande. Por lo que actualmente, no soy capaz de avanzar en la teoría
Javier se vuelca contigo en las mentorías. Pero en cada mentoría es imposible terminar las dudas que tiene cada uno y hay que agendar una o dos más.

Pienso que el curso se debería enfocar de otra manera. Cuando en el colegio te enseñan matemáticas, el profesor va haciendo el ejercicio a la vez que los alumnos van desarrollándolo. Creo que se debería hacer igual. Que todos fuéramos a la misma velocidad y si tenemos alguna duda, parar en ese momento para solucionarlo porque sino, esto se hace una bola de nieve y es imposible entender en qué punto estoy. Aquí te enseñan cosas que no sabes muy bien dónde aplicarlas al ejercicio y si te pierdes, es cosa tuya que tengas que solucionarte la vida. Veo que es una formación poco personalizada al estudiante teniendo en cuenta el valor del curso. Las materias me siguen pareciendo que no son las correctas con la exigencia que el mercado solicita.

As we have progressed in the program, the situation has improved: individual tutors were added, the option of group tutoring on Tuesdays and Thursdays was offered, and an extra teacher was included. Personally, after dedicating a lot of time to studying and doing and repeating exercises, I feel more prepared. The experience is positive, and my opinion about the bootcamp and the academy has improved.

It's noticeable that he has made an effort to improve. After the second survey we did, a change in the way classes were conducted was noticed. However, it gradually diminished in subsequent classes, but overall, there was improvement. I'm happy he's been part of this :)

It has been a good choice to add him to the program. His role in the breakout rooms has been very positive, bringing optimism and providing emotional support through relaxed conversations, as well as reviewing and commenting on projects and being available on Slack.
As we approach the final project and my experience it's being positive, I'd recommend this to friends and family...hope the last stage is as good as these last weeks.

This course is mostly quite efficient; the projects included in the program are very well done and help a lot when practicing. There is a lot of content and resources to learn.

Tim is a good mentor, his eagerness to teach and ensure that all students understand the content is noticeable. However, the teaching style (I'm not sure if it's required by the academy, or if it's just Tim's method) is not efficient for me (personally). I feel there is a lack of explanation in some areas. My biggest dissatisfaction lies with the breakout rooms. I would prefer it to be a teamwork effort among the entire class, following the teacher when explaining topics together as a class. The way people learn is different for everyone, and not everyone understands with this dynamic. Tim seems like a very intelligent person and knows what he's doing, but my suggestion is for him to understand each person learning style, because we are all different.

It has been good. The teachers and mentors are all very helpful! The projects are really tough. I wish there was more of a learning curve where the projects slowly get harder. It feels like they get really hard too quickly. I can't do most of them alone.

I would certainly spread the word and encourage others to learn this type of study, and 4Geeks seems to be a good avenue to increase your DS/ML knowledge base. I would perhaps leave them with a caution of what to expect and the availability that it takes to work through a time-compressed bootcamp!

I am definitely learning. The teachers and mentors are very nice and helpful. A few things I would change: 1) videos to watch as our lessons rather than the readings. Many of the readings are very hard to understand. 2) The projects giving you more guidance on how to approach it and how to plan how to do it. More instruction on walking you through it as well. There have been many many times where I am sitting at my computer for a few hours, not able to figure out what to do.

My experience in the program has been really interesting. The material is organized well, which has made it easier to grasp the concepts. However, there have been some challenges with the TA and teacher. The TA, while super nice, has seemed mentally absent and disinterested, often shopping online during sessions. Additionally, the teacher appears overwhelmed/tired at times, likely due to the lack of support and having to help all the students himself. Despite these challenges, I'm enjoying the learning process and staying focused on mastering the skills needed for this field.

My experience with my mentor, George Mihov, has been fantastic. He's incredibly patient and always willing to work with each student individually when needed. His explanations of the material are thorough and clear, making it easier to understand complex concepts. George is very informative and knowledgeable, and it's clear that he puts a lot of effort into helping us succeed. Despite having his hands full, he manages to provide excellent support and guidance. I feel lucky to have him as a mentor.

Creo que como indice para saber que aprender está bien, pero falta contenido en cuanto a fundamentos y conocimientos muy basicos, que al principio pensé que era por los profes, pero creo que es del Bootcamp en si. Por ejemplo, lo que hemos visto de React es muy light, y el salto de un par de hooks a Flux (donde no se explica muy bien que es exactamente) y y Context, te hace explotar la cabeza.

Para mejorar, si varios alumnos te dicen que no estan comodos con el profesor y te piden un cambio de profesor nada mas empezar el curso, teniendo en cuenta que es un curso corto (4 meses) creo que se le deberia dar mas importancia a ello...

Hasta el momento todo ha sido positivo. El curso tiene un ritmo apresurado pero llevadero. Veo correcto la manera de dar un poco de teoría, lo básico, para poder entender de un tipo de contenido y que cuando te enfrentes a un proyecto el alumno se ve obligado a buscar más información de la que le fue proporcionada. Es una buena práctica que fomenta el autoestudio, la fijación de los contenidos y desarrollo de habilidades.
Solo comentar que cuando por alguna circunstancia, te atrasas en un contenido con respecto al grupo, es un infierno ponerte al día (opino desde la propia experiencia)
Otro aspecto positivo a destacar es el catalogo de contenidos de la academia, sobretodo el de los proyectos. Ayuda mucho a los alumnos que se inician en el mundo de la programación a no tener que "pensar" que proyecto pudieran hacer para practicar.

Excelente, explica muy bien, te promueve las ganas de participar, y si no participa hace preguntas dirigidas. Igual le puedes escribir por slack para alguna duda o problema que se tenga y te asiste. Durante las clases del prework siempre dejaba un espacio libre después de la teoría y dividía el grupo en dos. Los que habían entregado el proyecto pues se iban a uno para que siguiera estudiando o reforzando otros contenidos; en el otro grupo ella se quedaba con los que estaban atrasados con las entregas de proyectos y para que ayudarlos si se atascaban. Esta metodología la encuentro excelente
Exelente mentoria, muy atenta a mis dudas y dispuesta ayudar con mucha paciencia.

I think it is really stupid to say that this is a fullstack dev course when seems that frontend part is focused only in learning a library like Bootstrap which may or may not be used in the future since there are a bunch more out there. Furthermore, in my experience which clients, when they ask for a website (or any other product which, somehow, will represent them), they'll be asking for a certain level of customization that won't be able to be achieved by a prototyped library like Bootstrap. In fact, even the hiring companies may not be using that library so, giving that importance to a single library instead of explaining the real coding languages will be handicap in the development of the students career

Rick Rodriguez. From day one, Rick brought an infectious enthusiasm to the classroom, matched by a deep understanding of both front-end and back-end technologies. Hi had a unique way of breaking down complex concepts into digestible parts, which was particularly helpful during the more intensive modules like JavaScript. He wasn't just about lectures; he ensured we got plenty of hands-on practice. For instance, during our project weeks, Rick would spend extra time with each of us, going over code and troubleshooting bugs. His patience was endless, and his one-on-one sessions were often where many breakthroughs happened.

What set Rick apart was his commitment to making sure no one fell behind. He held extra review sessions, sometimes extending past regular class hours, and was always available for a quick chat or to answer questions via our class Slack channel. His dedication was evident in the way he tailored his teaching methods to fit different learning styles.

Omar was more than just a TA; he was a mentor and a motivator who was genuinely invested in our success. His commitment was a huge factor in not only my achievements during the course but also in the positive and collaborative atmosphere of our class.

As my path coming to an end I have feeling that I am not ready to start project from zero and make it to the end.
He has knowledge but when he try to transfer that knowledge that doesn't work well. He is rushing trough lessons and it is hard for me to follow areas where I don't have previous experience.

Maybe it has to be this way since this bootcamp is really short in duration compared with others, but at this point I feel overwhelmed by how densely packed together the new concepts are in the lessons on the 4Geeks website. It seems like there is a lot of implicit knowledge that is not explicitely talked about, but we are still expected to use. 
On the other hand I am struggling with the little amount of instruction that is given in the projects. While this "do or die" approach makes you work really hard, I also feel that keeping the success rate reliably high is important both for motivation and progress (especially when you get several projects in a couple of days). One solution could be the addition of fully optional hints that guide you in the right direction.

The explainations are good.
However, it still feels as if questions are not an opportunity to go in depth and learn more, but an obstacle to get out of the way as soon as possible. Again, this might be a good and efficient approach for working as a dev, but it is not a good teaching tool/does not encourage me to actually ask something.
He knows a lot, and you can see it, he also explains everything

A nivel organizativo: la plataforma falla mucho, nos han cambiado de profesor de repente a mitad, el sistema de mentorias está cerrado a no ser que hables con el profesor, no se dan herramientas suficientes para entender como funciona la plataforma y la lección de GitHub debería ser la primera o incluso estar en el prework porque se debe usar desde el principio y nadie te explica cómo.

A nivel académico: el feedback de los proyectos es prácticamente inexistente, sólo aprobado o no, cuando seguro que hay muchas cosas que pueden comentar sobre tu trabajo que te ayuden a crecer. Los proyectos son demasiado simples o sólo abordan un caso de todos los que se dan en la teoría. La metodología de aula invertida y que aprendamos investigando y probando está bien, pero hay una diferencia entre eso y tener que ser 100% autónomos porque tu profesor nunca responde a tus preguntas, ni siquiera en las mentorias. Para ser totalmente autónoma no pago lo que vale el curso. Muy decepcionada.

Se supone que es nuestro primer contacto a la hora de solucionar problemas o tener mentorias y no vale absolutamente de nada preguntar. Además de hacer comentarios totalmente fuera de lugar, jamás responde a las preguntas. Prueba, investiga...estoy se acuerdo, pero cuando acudo a él ya he probado e investigado, jamás le he pedido que me solucione las cosas, le he hecho preguntas de índole conceptual para saber por dónde seguir investigando y probando y es incapaz de responder. Creo que no escucha o no entiende que se le pregunta por una guía no por la solución. Muy buen humor, eso sí, pero estamos aquí para aprender y no ayuda.

De entre varios bootcamp escogí 4Geeks porque un amigo había hecho el de Full Stack y estaba contento. Tras hablarlo con él veo que su experiencia fue muy diferente, así que algo está ocurriendo con el equipo que se encarga de éste.
Enseña muchos campos y es muy adictivo, algunas tareas son muy rápidas y otras llevan mas trabajo
Espero poder encontrar trabajo de ello, por ahora estoy contento con todo lo que estoy aprendiendo.

No creo que sea algo para "aprender a programar en 18w" " Convertirte en un programador" "Dar un cambio a tu carrera en 18w" por el precio, es un indice de lo que debe saber un programador. Espero que el apoyo para buscar trabajo después sea mejor.

Now that we're closer to the end, this final part, the back-end is feeling a bit rushed. This is a individual review but I've talked with some other students and it's a sentiment that is generalized. What is it that is missing? Can't really tell because you don't know what you don't know so it's hard to pin point, maybe a bit more context of it all, how things truly fit together in a working environment and not just in learning? Maybe?
Also, in more than one occurrence, I feel that whenever we have practice and exercises to assimilate new tools/skills the student experiences a really great and smooth transition but otherwise, when the module is built with the material and straight to a project it's harder to do that same transition. You manage to deliver the project, if you look back on it, now that you have the knowledge fully assimilated you find it to be extremely easy but during production you struggled so much.
Es mi salvación en el Bootcamp =) Super contenta con Miguel, explicaciones claras, sabe un montón de todo y en qué dudamos.

Personally I think he's not the best explaining things. And this is what i have a problem with. I am a spanish native speaker and i chose to do the course in english because that's the language in which programming languages are based. I thought it was going to make it easier for me to understand. But Nikhil's first language isn't english, so some things i get lost in translation. I find myself hearing explanations that sometimes are repetitive and classes most times seem to be him reading what we should have read ourselves. I learn something new every class, but i think i could have been learning much more if someone fluent was teaching it. He knows what he's doing, but he's not good transmitting that. He struggles finding the right words. It makes me regret not having done the course in spanish instead.
Recomiendo por la flexibilidad con la disponibilidad de los alumnos y también el contenido y actividades.

Tengo muchas ganas de acabar para empezar a aprender/practicar cosas específicas. El curso me ha abierto mucho los ojos al mundo de programación del que no tenía ni idea y ahora tengo una base para poder empezar de "verdad", aprovechare las tutorias con proyectos personales a tope

I'd like to suggest the project review should be mandatory even when it's approved. We don't know if we passed because it was good or was it barely enough? Even if it's good I'm sure there's things we could improve upon even if it is not extremely necessary at that point in time. I'm the kind of student that I usually do more in the projects than what is asked because I think it's good to explore more things and we're likely to have to learn those things later anyway but it ends up being ignored. It'd be nice to have a more detailed and feedback. If it's a score, general or by some criteria it's up to you of course.
It's in our best interest to know from people who actually work in the industry how we're coming along even though we still have so limited knowledge. Since we'll be trying to get a job after this course it's scary to think we're just ok. Just ok is not very competitive in the job market.

Un acompañamiento perfecto.

Como posibles mejoras el ritmo de las clases de backend era bastante acelerado, lo que a veces hacía difícil absorber toda la información dada la complejidad de los temas. Sería beneficioso para futuras cohortes considerar extender las horas de clase para este módulo o incluir más recursos complementarios para el estudio independiente. 
-- Incrementar la duración de las sesiones dedicadas a backend o añadir más sesiones de repaso.
-- Proporcionar materiales adicionales para estudio autónomo, como vídeos, tutoriales, o referencias a documentación adicional.
En cuanto al proyecto final, aunque valoro la flexibilidad de elegir nuestro propio tema, pienso que un enfoque más estructurado podría ser más beneficioso. Proyectos basados en escenarios reales o con requisitos más detallados podrían prepararnos mejor y mejorar la aplicabilidad de nuestras habilidades aprendidas.

La experiencia de momentos va con altibajos, hay muchas cosas positivas que me gustan de la academia, el compañerismo, los mentores como estan atentos casi 24/7, las clases puntuales, correcciones de ejercicio bien.. ahora lo que no me termina de agradar mucho es el profesor que nos ha tocado, no tanto por sus conocimientos, se nota que sabe mucho de codigo, y corrije bien, pero noto que le falta saber enseñar, es decir noto que le cuesta comunicarse para transmitir ese conocimiento y muchas veces las clases teóricas dan mucho que desear a mi gusto.. sin ir más lejos el ayudante Carlos Pozo, enseña mucho mejor, pero tiene menos conocimientos que el profesor.. enfin de momento es lo unico que no me gusta, el resto de la experiencia en general está bien.

Lo he comentado en el punto anterior, pero básicamente noto que le falta experiencia como "profesor" no como programador, entiende y sabe mucho del tema pero no logra transmitirlo, en las teóricas me cuesta mucho conectar sus explicaciones porque se traba mucho, es una gran persona y en cuanto a las correcciones de los proyectos genial porque critica constructivamente, pero le falta don de profesor, sabe mucho de código y se nota.

Me saco el sombrero con Carlos, siempre atento a todo, dispuesto, una persona tranquila y que se explaya muy bien, en las clases que tuvimos del prework tenia bastante bien organizada la clase teórica y creo que eso aportó muchísimo, 10 de 10.

Creo que de haber tenido una mejor experiencia en las clases teóricas con Miguel hubiera puntuado más, ya que siento que es un alto precio el que se paga por este tipo de bootcamp y tanto clases prácticas como teóricas tienen que estar a la altura, todavia me falta mucho por recorrer de la formación de todas formas, y es posible que al terminar sea otra la puntuación, pero de momento va asi.

It has been a grind, but I believe it will all be worthwhile in due time.  There have been moments of confusion, frustration, and doubt, but as I am sure with any new endeavor, these challenges can eventually be overcome with persistence.

Again, I would certainly recommend taking the course to those who are interested in furthering their education, just be sure that your decision is not made lightly and you are ready for a 'bootcamp'...that your presence will be needed and focus sharp for the entire duration of the course.
so far experience is good

No son tantas horas como me habían prometido, suele ser entre 30-45 minutos por día. El resto es resolver un ejercicio por tu cuenta. (Algo que ya pudieramos hacer por nuestra cuenta en tiempos libres).

Le comenté a mi esposa de que si veía bien el curso, le añadiríamos a estudiar lo mismo, pero hasta el momento falta mucho para que pueda recomendarlo, hasta ahora y por lo visto, no. (Solo van 2 semanas de clases), esperaremos un poco mas a ver que tal todo.
Robert (Alex) has been great.  The lectures have been thorough and informative, and he is quite knowledgable about the topics at hand.

excelente profesor, uno de los mejores mentores que he tenido. su forma de explicar, su dedicacion al codigo y a enseñar, su paciencia con los estudiantes, su punto de vista, su forma de como se dirije a nosotros... en serio es tremendo profesional y persona. Siento que la calidad del curso no es la esparada, por lo que se vende en redes sociales, premios mencionados y costo. Al menos este profesor creo (Gabri).
Las clases parecen que no son preparadas, se improvisa un poco y no se logran responder las consultas básicas que los alumnos preguntamos. La conexión a internet del profesor parece que no es muy buena porque se corta bastante y se pierde el hilo de la comunicación.
Hasta el momento esperaba clases de mayor calidad y contenido. No sé si será un profe que es más fuerte en backend, pero el inicio por ahora no es según lo esperado.
Por otro lado, este profesor no sé si llega a transmitir bien el contenido, quizás sabe de programación pero también hay que saber comunicarlo y tener cualidades para enseñar. En el prework, Javi Seigle por ejemplo, si me pareció que transmitía bien el contenido.
Fantástica! Super atenta a todos los detalles. Siempre se detiene a explicar lo que no entiendes y con mucha claridad.

los profesores perfecto, explican muy bien, el teacher assitant es increible (Gastón), pero pienso que la teoría que ofrece es de una calidad media... También aunque es full stack el curso, creo que si en el prework se dedicó tiempo a HTML y CSS, se deberia omitir en el bootcamp y dedicar mas tiempo al backend, porque el frontend va perfecto, pero el backend muy rapido y no da tiempo de procesar y entender tanta informacion
Es MUY bueno, pone muchos ejemplos y te puede explicar las cosas tanto muy técnicas como a bajo nivel para que se pueda entender. Me encantan sus clases.

Al igual que el profesor, creo que no he podido tener mas suerte con este teacher assistant. Es una persona muy atenta se preocupa por que entendamos las cosas, siempre agrega cosas a la explicación del profesor por si alguien no lo entendió, es maravilloso.
Excelente en la mentoría, Cecilia me ayudó a despejar todas las dudas que yo tenía!

Es muy pronto para ya juzgar en totalidad al curso, pero ya he comentado antes mis sensaciones hasta ahora.
Como recomendación, sería ideal hacer un examen de ingreso básico para que la gente sepa de qué se trata. Mucha gente se mete en los bootcamps por otros motivos ajenos a la programación (por que le gusta viajar y trabajar en cualquier parte del mundo por ejemplo), pero quizás se da cuenta que en realidad la programación no es los suyo pero ya está inscripta y con las cuotas pagándose mes a mes. De esa manera se filtraría la gente que realmente le interesa y le gusta al menos un poco programar, a otras personas que por gusto a viajar creen que es la profesión ideal (no digo que no, pero quizás no sea realmente su pasión).

I find myself wishing there was more in the course about actual work environment and project building because right now in the final project I'm struggling more than ever because most of my team has no idea how to structure the work or even have a good notion of the steps required in order to actually starting a project... It's all falling back on me as a student as well I don't think I should have to piggyback the other students... Maybe there could be some sort of threshold before being able to advance to the final project since I feel some people are overwhelmingly underprepared....

I understand all bootcamps might be the same in this regard but I feel very alone in this process in the sense that we might have some difficulties but want to persevere and end up doing good on our own. That means that unless we struggle a lot we don't really have that mentoring and feeling of being followed up because if everything is good then everything is good and that's all.
It would be nice to have a meeting summarization of key contents and how to use them.

La recomendaría solo a jóvenes que capaz no trabajan y no tienen demasiadas responsabilidades, de verdad puede ser muy desgastante para la gente que tiene que llegar de trabajar a darle a la mente a tratar de resolver proyectos y así y de paso compartiendo pantalla, de verdad es muy difícil

David explica muy bien. Se toma el tiempo de preparar la clase y brinda ejemplos que ayudan a digerir mejor la información. Me gusta mucho que está disponible gran parte del tiempo y que tiene la paciencia para repasar o repetir explicaciones.

Astrid suele aportar más durante las mentorias en cuanto a que se mete de cabeza en las consultas de los estudiantes y logra resolver las problemáticas presentadas. Está siempre muy dispuesta a ayudar y a resolver preguntas que hagan los estudiantes.
Buena en general, pero de verdad muy agotador y estresante
Buena
Muy bueno, me gustó mucho la dinámica.
Muy bueno, gran asesor, soluciones entendibles y metodología paso a pasito.
Excelente, de igual manera gran apoyo.
Si es una gran academia para iniciar en el mundo de la programación.

En general muy bien, la plataforma y la cursada, para sumar, siento que a veces las explicaciones en las clases podrían ser más contundentes, si bien son conceptos de introducción, pienso que a veces las explicaciones son muy generales, y eso a veces hace que no se comprenda muy bien el propósito de algunos conceptos. Creo que podría ayudar, dar una mirada más integral de los procesos y su interelación También sumar aspectos más técnicos a las explicaciones para entender bien los propósitos.

Muy buena! José es muy amable y predispuesto. Como recomendación para mejorar, podría aportar, ser más técnico en las explicaciones. Aportar una visión más especifica de los procesos, el porqué y la inter-relación de cada herramienta. A veces las explicaciones pueden ser muy generales y creo que ser más específico puede aportar en la comprensión de los estudiantes.
Hasta ahora, ha sido excelente. no tengo ninguna queja
siento que ya habiamos respondido esta pregunta hace 2 semanas. Me parece excelente, si pudiera tener a david para explicarme todo sobre codigo en la vida, lo haria.
Astrid ha sido genial. Me ha ayudado a resolver dudas, siempre esta atenta y sus mentorias han sido muy utiles
súper, ahorita en el proyecto final nos impulsa y presiona más y más para que logremos llegar y es increíble
Astrid es muy compresiva y está siempre al pendiente para ayudar, al igual que está detrás de ti si te falta algo para ayudarte y aportarte
ya lo he hecho !!!!

De momento no siento que las clases aporten un extra a las lecturas que realizamos antes de éstas. Preparamos la clase, hay una pequeña parte de teoría que consiste en repasar esas lecturas y luego nos dividimos en grupos que, en muchas ocasiones acaban siendo para ayudar a compañeros que van más retrasados con sus proyectos, que no me parece mal, pero no siento que las clases sean realmente ese aporte de valor extra que no tiene el ser autodidacta, aunque Juan pone todo su empeño y energía en ello! Además, en algunos temas me da la sensación de que el orden de explicar la materia se siente un poco desordenado, hacemos ejercicios y proyectos de los que se explica el funcionamiento una o dos clases después. Por otra parte siento que estamos repitiendo muchas cosas del prework que, aunque contaba con volver a verlas, esperaba que fuera con otros ejercicios o ejemplos, que al final buscas en más plataformas para complementar.

El hecho de ser exalumna del mismo bootcamp hace que pueda empatizar mucho con nosotros. Me gusta que no nos dé la solución a las dudas, si no que nos guía para que nosotros mismos intentemos encontrarlas.

Creo que tiene que avanzar más el bootcamp para saber si realmente recomendaría a algún familiar o amigo que se inscribiese. Es un desembolso muy elevado, y de momento no está acorde con las herramientas o conocimientos adquiridos, pero cuento con que eso cambie a medida que avance nuestra formación.
Bastante completa con mucha ayuda de nuestros tutores
Excelente, siempre atento y explica las veces que sea necesario. Disponibilidad 100%!
Cada día me gusta más la academia

A todo el que desee incursionar en el mundo de la tecnología le recomendare a mil la academia 4Geeks. Como dije en mi respuesta inicial; el hecho de poder pasar de tener un conocimiento básico sobre algún lenguaje de programación y de ahí pasar a realizar algún producto o proyecto me parece sorprendente.

Buena, explica muy bien y de verdad es muy paciente a la hora de explicar, lo único que podría comentar como crítica constructiva quizá es que le gusta dejar cosas por fuera de la explicación a veces y nos lo deja de “tarea” pero la verdad es que estoy pagando un curso porque necesito que alguien me enseñe esta información, no para que me manden a googlearla, entiendo que es para desarrollar skills de investigación y así, pero créanme que igual hay que investigar muchas cosas, para que además dejen cosas esenciales por fuera de la explicación y allá que investigar y tratar de entender la información que de paso siempre está en inglés para entonces poder terminar un proyecto que de por si tiene un tiempo límite es muy estresante la verdad

Excelente, La metodologia, las Clases en vivo, los eventos en meet o en youtube y los mentores me han ayudado mucho en este proceso. no ha sido facil para mi este proceso por varios motivos. sin embargo me alegro he sentido Comodo, Agradecido y super Apoyado con el Profesor Deimian Vazquez, Jose Caro, Yorkfran Abreu, Bryan Gracia y Octavio Lara. me siento super bien de formar parte de su academia y de aprender cada uno de ustedes.

excelente, he estado en 3 cohortes, y de mis 3 mentores quiero destacar que con mi profesor Jose Caro admiro su atencion al Detalle con respecto al codigo, el me ha asesorado de forma asertiva sin presionarme pero tampoco dejandomela facil... me hace pensar el porque de las cosas, el que significa cada parte del codigo. me motiva a aprender cada dia mas y en no caer en la trampa de ir a lo Facil....

claro que si, jejeej ya lo estoy haciendo con mis compañeros de la universidad, en mis redes sociales, a mis compañeros de trabajos y a todas esas persona que como yo, quieren aprender, repasar e incluirse realmente a esta industria. son una excelente academia. pero aun mas que eso... ustedes cuentan con un personal que realmente son Humanos y estan dispuesto a realmente acompañar a sus estudiantes. nos ven mas que solo un numero...  para mi ustedes son mas que una academia... son una Familia... de momento lo recomiendo, aunque no descarto mas opciones, teniendo en cuenta la poca flexibilidad horaria a la hora de las clases, que te sesgan a un horario en concreto y para personas que tienemos horarios rotativos, puede ser un problema.

La evolución del curso creo que no ha sido del todo buena. Se ha pasado demasiado tiempo en la parte básica y apenas se le ha dedicado atención a la parte más compleja. Una vez que se llegó a React la carrera ha ido demasiado rápida, por no hablar de python que tras una clase se nos ha pedido crear una api directamente. Además, no le veo el sentido a como se ha tratado todo el backend, me explico, hicimos por enésima vez los mismos ejercicios de wally, beattles etc... y a la siguiente clase se nos pide una cosa que no tiene nada que ver cuando lo lógico habría sido empezar por algo más sencillo. Además, las últimas clases han sido una cosa distinta detrás de otra, entiendo que por necesidad del curso y tiempo es la forma que hay, pero quizá sea mejor ampliar el curso 1 mes más para afianzar conocimientos.

No sé si él, ha seguido un método marcado por 4geeks, pero en respecto a clases , leer un powerpoint (el cuál ya me había leído al hacerme los apuntes de la clase previamente), y mandarnos hacer un ejercicio, creo que no es lo que yo esperaba, a partir de flux....las cosas fueron así, los ejercicios que hemos tenido que hacer tenían videos que ocupaban mínimo una hora, y no nos daba tiempo a hacer código, y por lo tanto  a encontrar dudas, que se generaban fuera de la clase. Además a veces en mi caso los ejercicios, debido a mi falta de experiencia, posiblemente eran un poco confusos empezarlos...
He echado en falta mentorías por su parte, las cuales creo que me hubieran venido muy bien, ya que él desarrollador es el ,  y he recibido esas clases por los teacher asistant de 4geeks, que me han ayudado mucho..
Pero recalco, que su modus operandi, no sé si ha sido por él o por la forma que hay predifinida de dar las clases, igualmente cuando han surgido dudas en la clase todo perfecto!

Pues en mi caso, creo que han sobrado muchos chistes y comentarios graciosos, que realmente no tenían gracia, comentarios que pueden ser divertidos en tu circulo, pero que no debes de hacer en un grupo donde no conoces a la gente ,y además eres el guía del grupo, porque venimos a aprender a hacer código, no a escuchar tonterías machistas, racistas o xenofobas, que lo siento, en muchos casos me ha dado verguenza ajena.
Los compañeros del curso que digan lo que quieran, pero un teacher asistant, en mi opinión no debe entrar en ese juego, que puede ofender a gente dentro del grupo.

Creo que los teacher assintat que están formando parte de mi formación, me están ayudando mucho, he notado una falta de mentores al principio, y no sé si la notaré en los proyectos finales, pero, es verdad que se solucionó en menos de una semana y eso es de alabar por vuestra parte, y da a entender que os preocupáis y dais soluciones.
Me gustaría dar una valoración más concisa cuando termine, realmente, y ver realmente el resultado, creo que es un proceso largo y no solo podemos valorarlo ahora , aún falta mucho

Dear Rick,

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to express my sincere gratitude for the invaluable mentorship you have provided me throughout the Full-Stack Software Developer 18-week program. Your guidance, support, and encouragement have significantly enhanced my learning experience and have been instrumental in my development as an aspiring software developer.

From our very first meeting, your approachable and supportive demeanor put me at ease. You have consistently made yourself available to answer questions, provide feedback, and offer advice, which has greatly boosted my confidence. Your deep knowledge of both front-end and back-end technologies has been incredibly inspiring and has motivated me to strive for excellence in my studies.

One of the most impactful aspects of your mentorship has been your ability to break down complex concepts into manageable and understandable parts. Whether it's explaining the intricacies of JavaScript frameworks or guiding me through
good
very good
I really like the way that 4Geeks academy designed their programing classes for their students and I already recommended a few of my friends the 4Geeks Academy
Omar is responsive, making himself available to address any questions or challenges I encounter.
Donald has been incredibly supportive and knowledgeable, offering valuable guidance and feedback throughout my journey in the Full-Stack Software Developer course.

The balance between theory and practical exercises was well-maintained, allowing me to apply what I learned in real-world projects. These hands-on projects were particularly valuable, as they provided a deeper understanding and helped solidify my skills.

Rick is always approachable and responsive, making himself available for any questions or concerns I have, no matter how big or small. His practical insights and real-world experience have been particularly beneficial, helping me understand how to apply what I’ve learned in real-world scenarios.

The comprehensive and well-structured curriculum, combined with the excellent support from instructors and mentors, has made my learning experience incredibly rewarding. The hands-on projects and real-world applications of the material have significantly enhanced my skills and confidence as a Full-Stack Software Developer.

I was expecting a certain level of expertise from the students and so far I feel like many of them don't understand a lot of basic concepts,  like how to create an if conditional in the form if(){}.  I feel like we are stuck and I don't know if it is expected but I just want to make sure that I can learn the necessary skills to obtain a job in the industry. I thought there was some sort of selection with the Pre-work. Out of that, I think that there are many highly skilled mentors and that does increase the value of the course.

Dillon is an expert in programming and when you ask a question to him, he always helps you find an answer to a coding problem. I just feel like sometimes we just stick to lectures and I am not entirely sure if he gives additional ideas, like his own perspective.

I think that there are a lot of good exercises, and the mentors are a really valuable resource. Just again, I think that the level of some students is very low and that makes me think sometimes that I am not going to be able to attain a high level of expertise in software development. I just feel like there should be a minimum level to enter the program. It is too early in the program, so I am sure there is still a lot to learn and hopefully students will catch up.

 I also need to see the rest of the material. I have enjoyed this so far although I am not sure that all of the projects are related to what we will be asked to do in the real world. For example, The Excuse generator is very similar to the Domain Generator, and it was done twice, so it feels a bit repetitive sometimes. I am yet to work with mentors for career support but I am expecting it to be another valuable resource. 

In general good and accessible in terms of price. I am hoping it depends on the student at the end.

Just to those who have the financial means to pay in full without it being a very big investment, who are developers already and would like to change field of work, and who have a lot of time on their hands.

Very clever man. Clearly knows his stuff but has a tendency to waffle instead of taking the time ALL this time later to stop, check for comprehension and THEN proceed. He only did this for maybe two modules towards the end of the course. As soon as the Final Project started, I was barey there for 5 minutes before being dumped into a 'Breakout Room' then no matter how many times I pressed the 'Raise Hand' function - I got nowhere. Waiting sometimes in excess of 30 mins in a mere class of 6 or less. Same problem - When I was clearly overwhelmed, I was being told ¨Oh, that's easy, all you do is... ¨*begins excessive instructions* - My head turns off. Too much. If you're not going to use certified teachers - fine but just make sure they can teach. Like Fernanda.
Wouldn't make much difference if he wasn't there in my opinion.

For someone with programming experience only - This was NOT for beginners whatsoever. It has been a drain of four months and has destroyed my confidence and curiosity in this field and I hope to never see it again.
